content: As we enter April, caring for those sick with Covid-19 and preventing others from becoming so remains the priority in New York City, as in the rest of the country. But how can we look out for others particularly affected by the crisis? Citywide closures of nonessential services have devastated the arts at every level: Exhibition and performance spaces have shuttered indefinitely, and thousands of New Yorkers working in creative industries, many of them freelancers, have seen their livelihoods disappear with no assurances about when they’ll be able to work again. Many of these people also work in bars and restaurants, the closures of which threaten to change the face of the industry forever — the longer a restaurant stays closed, restaurateurs will tell you, the harder it will be to reopen.

It’s been five days of work at the kitchen table, on the couch, in the basement, wherever you can perch where, in my case, there’s not a child in virtual school or a spouse on a video call, a cat stretched out in the sun, the dog looking ready, again, for a walk. Then dinner, say pizza chicken (above), hastily prepared just as it was before the coronavirus came, and served too late, before everyone tips into bed to start all over again in the gray light of morning. Five days of this at least.

title: Corrections: April 3, 2020

content: An article on Wednesday about the spread of coronavirus through asymptomatic cases misstated the location of a choir that developed many cases of coronavirus infection. Its covert spread set off a pandemic in ways other coronaviruses did not; it was not the first virus other than influenza to cause a pandemic. description: Today’s propaganda is tomorrow’s truth, and vice versa.
content: Other than a vaccine or an extra 500,000 ventilators, tests and hospital beds, reliable information is the best weapon we have against Covid-19. It allows us to act uniformly and decisively to flatten the curve. In an ideal pandemic scenario, sound information is produced by experts and travels quickly to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James E. Baker
title: It’s High Time We Fought This Virus the American Way
description: The administration has all the authority it needs to produce medical supplies and prepare for a potential vaccine.
content: Every Marine knows better than to pull a knife in a gunfight. But so far, that appears to be the federal government’s approach to battling Covid-19. The president has “invoked” the Defense Production Act, but the government has not used the full authority of the act. There is a difference between invoking a law and using it, just as there is a difference between talk and action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bari Weiss
title: The Men and Women Who Run Toward the Dying
description: Meet the New York City chaplains praying for coronavirus patients.
content: Few run toward the dying. Even fewer run toward the contagious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: Film Treasures, Streaming Courtesy of the Library of Congress
description: The astonishment of riches includes up-close looks at our history in hundreds of films. And they’re all free.
content: One of the world’s oldest films, “Sneeze,” is a gift that keeps on giving. Shot in 1894 and about as long as an achoo, it shows a mustachioed gent emitting a single sneeze, a kerchief clutched in one hand. The film was made by W.K.L. Dickson and the sneeze delivered by Fred Ott. Working in Thomas Edison’s New Jersey studio, they gave us the first celluloid sneeze, an open-mouth exhalation that was meant to be humorous but today seems ominous. Cover your mouth! I yelled when I looked at it again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Gift From Gallaghers: Aged Steaks for First Responders
description: On Friday, the New York steakhouse opened its famed front-window meat locker to police officers and firefighters.
content: The first thing you see when you walk into Gallaghers Steakhouse, a 93-year-old restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, is steak. In the glass-paneled meat locker in the steakhouse’s front window are cut after cut of prime beef — a Fort Knox of meat, tagged and aging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Murphy
title: Stop Using Toilet Paper
description: Why are we hoarding it when experts agree that rinsing with water is more sanitary and environmentally sound?
content: While the coronavirus pandemic is affecting us all differently depending on where we live, our financial situation and our basic health, one universal is the difficulty finding toilet paper.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.Y. Virus Deaths Double in Three Days to Almost 3,000
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that there had been 562 deaths due to the virus over the previous 24 hours, a higher toll than the state saw in the first 27 days of March.
content: The coronavirus was taking lives at a devastating pace in New York on Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said, with deaths nearly doubling in just three days, from 1,550 on Tuesday to 2,935 on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Swift Aid Payments Keep Berlin’s Self-Employed Afloat Despite Shutdown
description: Within days, Germany’s capital distributed money to 150,000 artists, shop owners, hairdressers and other small-business owners and freelancers to cover basic expenses.
content: BERLIN — When Germany shut down public life to halt the spread of the new coronavirus last month, Laurenz Bostedt, a freelance photographer, watched as one contract after another was canceled, until his entire expected income had disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bill Withers, Who Sang ‘Lean on Me’ and ‘Ain’t No Sunshine,’ Dies at 81
description: A three-time Grammy Award winner, he had a string of much-covered hits in the 1970s but had not released an album since 1985.
content: Bill Withers, a onetime Navy aircraft mechanic who, after teaching himself to play the guitar, wrote some of the most memorable and often-covered songs of the 1970s, including “Lean on Me,” “Ain’t No Sunshine” and “Use Me,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tweed Roosevelt
title: Captain Crozier Is a Hero
description: Theodore Roosevelt, my great-grandfather, would agree.
content: On Monday, Capt. Brett Crozier, the commander of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, sent a letter to the Navy pleading for permission to unload his crew, including scores of sailors sickened with Covid-19, in Guam, where it was docked. The Pentagon had been dragging its feet, and the situation on the ship was growing dire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: European Soccer Teams Get Clarity and a Warning
description: European soccer leaders have written to teams and leagues to map out a plan to return to action in July and August, warning there would be consequences should leagues abandon seasons unilaterally.
content: European soccer leaders have told teams to plan for a return to action in July and August and issued a threat by suggesting leagues that cancel the season face the risk of their teams being barred from the Champions League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: U.S. Women’s Open Postponed Until December
description: The event, originally slated for early June, is the third women’s golf major tournament to be rescheduled. The decision may augur a decision from the U.S. Golf Association on the men’s Open.
content: The United States Golf Association postponed the 75th United States Women’s Open from early June to mid-December on Friday, a notable sign that golf’s governing bodies are seriously weighing dates late this year as they scramble to reschedule an ever-expanding list of postponed women’s and men’s events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Ken Shimura, Comedian Whose Sketches Delighted Japan, Dies at 70
description: His slapstick humor, physical comedy and naïve persona made him a household name in the country for decades.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elsa Dixler
title: Patricia Bosworth, Actress-Turned-Author, Dies at 86
description: She gave up the stage for the writing life, publishing biographies of some famous friends and two powerful memoirs. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘I Refuse to Be Repentant’: The Woman Challenging Uganda’s Ruler
description: Stella Nyanzi mixes profanity and bawdy humor with razor-sharp political insights to criticize the country’s autocratic president.
content: KAMPALA, Uganda — The tears began flowing immediately after Stella Nyanzi began to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Clifford Krauss and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Trump Promotes Oil Deal That May Not Exist
description: The president’s optimism for a deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce production and a Saudi call for talks send crude prices skyrocketing, but Moscow showed little enthusiasm.
content: WASHINGTON — When oil prices crashed in early March after a dispute between Russia and Saudi Arabia, President Trump put a positive spin on the news. “Good for the consumer, gasoline prices coming down!” he wrote on Twitter as markets tumbled. On Tuesday, Mr. Trump said that falling gasoline prices amounted to “the greatest tax cut we’ve ever given.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. Threatens Legal Action Against Sellers of Fake Coronavirus Cleaners
description: The federal government is asking online retailers to take unregistered products that falsely claim protection from coronavirus off the market.
content: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency warned Friday that disinfectants and sanitizers falsely claiming to protect against the coronavirus are flooding the market and threatened legal action against retailers that sell unregistered products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Five Signs of Failure
description: No. 1: No sign of a flattening curve.
content: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Dwyer
title: The Doctor Came to Save Lives. The Co-op Board Told Him to Get Lost.
description: When an emergency room doctor traveled from New Hampshire to battle the coronavirus in New York, he moved into his brother’s building … but not for long.
content: At the end of seven hours in mask, gown and gloves at Bellevue Hospital Center on Monday, Dr. Richard Levitan finally had a chance to look at his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How to Thrive in Online Life
description: A video game pro tells us to embrace the mess of our pandemic lives.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yangyang Cheng
title: Of the Virus and God, Orange Peels and the Party
description: A mother and daughter write through distance and disease, searching for the other’s love.
content: CHICAGO — My mother believes that God and the Chinese Communist Party will defeat the novel coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis, Niraj Chokshi and David Gelles
title: Take Government Aid? We’ll See, Some Businesses Say
description: Executives at Boeing, for one, have indicated that they might not accept money authorized by the stimulus if they dislike the terms.
content: Grants, low-interest loans and other government support might seem like manna for businesses under financial strain. But some chief executives and corporate boards might balk at the offer of billions of dollars in aid to help them ride out the coronavirus pandemic and keep the economy from sliding into a deep recession.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Return of the Governor
description: Once considered bit players on the national stage, governors are emerging as some of the most prominent political voices in the coronavirus crisis.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Seeing Abortion Laws From a Teenager’s Point of View
description: Eliza Hittman explains how she came to make her timely odyssey “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” the unusual movie about abortion rights that makes bureaucracy the villain.
content: Before writing her new movie, “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” about the odyssey of a 17-year-old girl in present-day Pennsylvania seeking a legal abortion, the director Eliza Hittman embarked on a journey of her own. Hittman makes movies of quietly operatic intensity about vulnerable characters in unremarkable places. To find their narratives, she begins in the field, exploring prospective locations like a sculptor wandering a quarry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: As Virus Threatens Orchestras, Trade Group Taps a New Leader
description: The League of American Orchestras chose Simon Woods, who left the Los Angeles Philharmonic abruptly last September, as its next chief executive.
content: With arts organizations reeling from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, and bracing for worse, the League of American Orchestras has chosen a new leader to help guide its field through a bruising period. The league announced on Friday that Simon Woods, a longtime orchestra administrator, would be its next chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Sohn
title: What to Do if Your Day Care Is Still Open
description: And what to do if it isn’t. (For starters: Pay them if you can, but don’t fret if you can’t.)
content: Every morning when Inna Keselman goes to work as a neurologist at the University of California, Los Angeles, she drops her 3-year-old son off at a day care center located on campus. It’s the same routine that she had before the Covid-19 pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marilyn Stasio
title: Stashed in the Marsh, Left in the Road: Victims Pile Up in Four New Crime Novels
description: In Marilyn Stasio’s latest column, the body count is high and the murderers more cunning than ever.
content: The voices of the dead tell the unhappy story of PLEASE SEE US (Gallery, 341 pp., $26.99), Caitlin Mullen’s spellbinding debut novel about a series of murders in Atlantic City. When the narrative opens, there are two dead women sprawled in the marsh behind the Sunset Motel. By the end of the story, there will be seven of these Jane Does, all victims of a killer who targets prostitutes, the most disposable of women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: To Safeguard Its Future, Tennis Seeks Unity. Even With the French Open.
description: As play is delayed to at least mid-July, small tournaments and many players are at risk of significant financial losses, and the French Open’s unilateral rescheduling has added to the chaos.
content: With tennis shut down amid the coronavirus pandemic, the game is still playing for its future as Roger Federer practices trick shots in the snow against a wall at home in Switzerland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: How Do You Make a Film for a Museum and Pornhub? Ask Leilah Weinraub
description: The director captured the utopia that was Shakedown, a strip club catering to black lesbians. The result was a radically intimate documentary suited to both platforms.
content: The moment Leilah Weinraub stepped into Shakedown, a roving lesbian strip club in Los Angeles, she was hooked. It was the winter of 2002, she was a recent college graduate, and Shakedown, which was part of a scene that catered to black lesbians, offered a tantalizing new community. “I had never been in a lesbian space that was full before,” Weinraub said. She immediately breezed her way into serving as house photographer for the parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Ravenscraft
title: Why Talking About Our Problems Helps So Much (and How to Do It)
description: There’s more to the age-old advice to just “talk it out” than there seems. Here’s some of the evidence that explains why it is so helpful.
content: When your car breaks down, you either know how to fix it or how to find someone who can. Emotions, on the other hand, are a little harder to fix. There is no wrench you can grab or repair shop you can take your feelings to. But you do have one tool in your kit you can always use: talking about your feelings. Even just speaking about your feelings out loud to another person can help. So why do we avoid it or believe it doesn’t work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Marin
title: How to Help Your Relationship Survive a Lockdown
description: Coronavirus-related anxiety is real and causing serious damage to our partnerships. Here are some tips to ease the strain.
content: The strain that the coronavirus is putting on our lives is immense. And it is affecting most relationships in some way. As a licensed psychotherapist specializing in relationship therapy, I’ve received many emails and calls in the past few weeks from concerned people worrying that their relationships were not going to make it.

title: Can an Old Vaccine Stop the New Coronavirus?

title: Half the World Is On Lockdown. For Sports? More Like 99 Percent.
description: What follows is the sum total of sporting events being held on our planet. Plus, a really fast cyclist on Zwift.
content: As the host of the 2020, we mean the 2021, Summer Games, Japan has drawn an outsize share of attention during the coronavirus pandemic. While it did shut down some events as early as February, and closed schools in March, it was slower to adopt some other mitigation efforts like working from home and social distancing, in part because its infection rates seemed low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simone Hannah-Clark
title: An I.C.U. Nurse’s Coronavirus Diary
description: I’ve started to refer to the time before this as peace time. Because this feels like a war.
content: I’m awake before my alarm goes off. I make coffee, wash my face and put deodorant on twice. The deodorant is never enough to stop the sweat and smell, but I try. My husband and kids are still asleep. I try to eat. My stomach turns as I imagine what today will bring, though of course I know. It’s always variations on the same theme: Critically ill patients who all have been given the same diagnosis, Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Governor Who Dissed New Yorkers
description: I just hate it when my fellow Italian-Americans squabble.
content: When every other Democrat in America was swooning over Andrew Cuomo, Gina Raimondo was sparring with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Avi S. Olitzky
title: I Never Used My Computer on the Sabbath — Until the Coronavirus
description: The pandemic is inspiring a rabbi to appreciate the Jewish practice of Shabbat in new ways.
content: Two Saturdays ago was the first time I used my computer on Shabbat in over 20 years. I was leading and participating in my congregation’s Zoom Minyan — our Cyber Shul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill de Blasio
title: Bill de Blasio: We Need All Medical Workers on the Front Lines
description: Our city and all cities need the federal government to enlist all doctors and health workers, and mobilize them in a way we’ve never seen.
content: There is no historical comparison for what our country is going through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: You Have an Extra 3 Months to File Your Taxes. Should You Wait?
description: If you’re owed a refund, it may be better to file quickly. You can also file your return now but wait until July 15 to pay any taxes owed.
content: The government has granted everyone an extra three months to file — and pay — their 2019 federal income taxes because of the coronavirus turmoil. Whew! It helps to have wiggle room in uncertain times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: National Security Court Orders Deeper Look at 29 F.B.I. Wiretap Applications
description: The rare public order follows an inspector general’s findings of pervasive problems with how the bureau has prepared applications to wiretap people.
content: WASHINGTON — A secretive court that oversees national security surveillance ordered the F.B.I. on Friday to conduct a searching review of 29 wiretap applications in terrorism and espionage investigations, after an inspector general uncovered pervasive problems with how the bureau prepared them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Emily Flitter
title: Frenzy and Desperation as Small Businesses Grab for Government Aid
description: A $349 billion program to throw them a financial lifeline got off to a rocky start on Friday as the U.S. economy continued to seize up.
content: The frenzy began even before most banks opened. By 9 a.m. on Friday, banks had already processed 700 loans totaling $2.5 million for small businesses as the spigot opened on a federal emergency relief program. But that was just the beginning. By early afternoon that number had ballooned to $1.8 billion. And by evening it was $3.2 billion in loans that will go to more than 10,000 small businesses desperate to save themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Cao Li
title: China Pushes for Quiet Burials as Coronavirus Death Toll Is Questioned
description: Officials are ​trying to curb expressions of grief and control the narrative​ amid doubts about the official number of deaths in China.
content: Liu Pei’en held the small wooden box that contained his father’s remains. Only two months ago, he had helplessly clutched his father’s frail hand as the elderly man took his last breath, and the pain was still raw. He wept.

author: By Michael Barbaro
title: Calling Dr. Fauci
description: Our interview with the nation’s top infectious disease specialist.
content: For weeks, our team has talked about trying to interview Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease specialist, about the coronavirus pandemic. He’s a unique figure in this crisis: a 30-year student of global epidemics, from H.I.V. to H1N1; a member of President Trump’s coronavirus task force; and one of two doctors, along with Dr. Deborah Birx, assigned by the White House to explain this emergency to the public through daily briefings and interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga, Remy Tumin and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The C.D.C. advised all Americans, even those who appear to be healthy, to wear a mask when they leave home.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advised all Americans — even people who appear to be healthy — to cover their face with a mask or a scarf when they leave home to help slow the spread of the coronavirus in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: The Navy Fired the Captain of the Theodore Roosevelt. See How the Crew Responded.
description: The rousing show of support provided another gripping scene to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic: the rank and file cheering a boss they viewed as putting their safety ahead of his career.
content: WASHINGTON — It was a send-off for the ages, with hundreds of sailors aboard the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt cheering Capt. Brett E. Crozier, the commander who sacrificed his naval career by writing a letter to his superiors demanding more help as the novel coronavirus spread through the ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz and Davey Alba
title: ‘Zoombombing’ Becomes a Dangerous Organized Effort
description: Zoom, the videoconferencing app, has become a target for harassment and abuse coordinated in private off-platform chats.
content: In recent weeks, as schools, businesses, support groups and millions of individuals have adopted Zoom as a meeting platform in an increasingly remote world, reports of “Zoombombing” or “Zoom raiding” by uninvited participants have become frequent.
source.name: The New York Times
